Chapter 3, Part 2: All the Princes Holding the Crown Prince's Hand At that time, the prince knelt with his palms joined and respectfully bowed to the king, saying:

The giving I practice is not out of greed, anger, or ignorance, not for fame, not seeking rebirth among humans or gods, not out of arrogance, not out of insanity or confusion, but for the sake of the true Dharma that I practice giving.
Great King!
You should know that although I now protect my parents, brothers, wife, and children, when I die, even if I have relatives, who can follow me?
Only the true Dharma will follow me and not abandon me.
If I have no intention of practicing good dharmas, I still hope that the great king will admonish me with harsh words. How can you believe the wrong words and cut off my practice of good today?
The king first orders the minister to give, but the mind of giving is the minister's fundamental nature. How can it be given away?
It is like the nature of earth, which cannot abandon solidity;
up to the nature of fire, which cannot abandon heat;
if a fish is thrown onto land, how can it survive?
If the king's servant has all six faculties complete and a perfect body no different from the gods, how can such a person be the king's servant?
Where did the king's carriages, concubines, gold, silver, and precious treasures come from?
Know that they all come from the karmic results of past giving.
Great King!
Know that all hungry ghosts, tormented by the fire of hunger, with their bodies and minds scorched, are all due to the causes and conditions of greed and stinginess.
If among the gods there are palaces of the seven treasures with long lifespans, know that they are all due to the causes and conditions of giving.
Great King!
The gifts I now make cannot be burned by fire, cannot be carried away by water, and cannot be invaded or stolen by the royal family, thieves, enemies, or creditors.
In all destinies, it can act as a friend. These are the gifts that are carried by the heavens;
In the midst of birth and death, it follows my body, like a calf following its mother.
As the king has ordered, if he wants me to stop the mind of giving, if I cannot let go, I should be exiled to a deep mountain;
Even if I reach a deep mountain, if the mind of giving does not cease, poor people will also come.
I originally vowed to truly enjoy the mountains and forests. The reason I did not inform you was because I feared my father would not let me go.
Now that the great king has already approved, I truly obtain my original vow. I will immediately take my leave and set out on the road.
Why is this?
In the mountains and forests, this is a quiet place enjoyed by immortals and sages. It can leave behind greed, anger, and delusion. If I reach there, I will surely be able to benefit myself.
At that time, the prince immediately bowed at the king's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, and took his leave to depart;
Next, he went to his mother, knelt and paid homage as usual, circumambulated her three times to the right, bowed at her feet, and left;
Then, he went to his wife and said:
You should stay here well, make offerings to your parents, protect your son, and this is your practice of the true Dharma.
Now I want to go far to the mountains and forests.
Why is it so?
In the past, I always wished to enter the deep mountains and practice my aspirations.
My father, the king, now permits it, so I should quickly go there to fulfill my heart;
Together with the birds and beasts as my companions, eating fruits and berries to sustain myself;
You are a princess, with a soft body and upright and elegant, how can you endure such hardships? Therefore, you should stay here and do not need to follow me.

When his wife heard this, her heart was overwhelmed with distress. Her body trembled like a plantain leaf. She wept sorrowfully, beating her chest and pulling out her hair. She cried out loudly, exclaiming:
Alas!
What crime has my husband committed that the king has banished him to the deep mountains?
The great king is kind and compassionate, ruling with the right Dharma, loving the people like his own children. How can he suddenly banish him like this?
My husband's beloved body is soft and supple like a champak flower. How can he now lie down on thorns, earth, and stones?
If he were now in the palace, he would enjoy the five kinds of music. If he enters the mountains, he will only hear the ferocious sounds of tigers, wolves, lions, and poisonous beasts.
Strange!
Where is the great king's compassionate heart today?
How can a father suddenly become estranged over a small matter and become an enemy?
At that time, the prince replied to his wife, saying:
Excellent!
Princess!
You have deep wisdom, diligence, and courage. You are my good companion. Even if I am not worthy, you should still rebuke me. How can you speak such coarse words?

The kings fight each other for the sake of the country, all because of being troubled by greed, anger, and delusion. It is my good fortune that the king allows me to enter the mountains to practice the true Dharma. You should not be unhappy now.

The constant law in the world is that if a king becomes old and weak, he establishes a crown prince to manage the affairs of the state. The affairs of the state are busy and have many faults. Once the faults befall one, there is no place to escape.

The king is not yet weak, yet he is able to let go and listen to me entering the mountains to cultivate and study his intentions. The faults of the world will never be seen again. Why are you unhappy now?
You can stay well, I now want to leave.
He replied:
When my parents were with you, the sun, moon, earth, and the four heavenly kings all bore witness.
On the day of our marriage, you yourself vowed not to abandon me. How can you now want to go alone?
Know that the sun and moon, as well as fierce fire, are bright and substantial, not abandoning each other. How can you now want to abandon me?
At that time, the prince used all his family wealth to give to the poor. He carried the two children on his shoulders, took his wife by the hand, and went to the Himalayas.
When the prince arrived, he ate fruits, drank water, and sustained his life. Day and night he cultivated the mind of kindness and compassion. He further thought like this:
Although I experienced the five desires at home, it is not like the joy of being in the mountains today. Such joy is not experienced by Åšakra DevÄnÄm Indra.
These sentient beings do not know the subtle taste of the true Dharma, like crows who do not know the taste of lotus flowers.
At that time, the prince always contemplated this meaning for the sake of sentient beings, and his wife always entered the mountains to pick fruits to provide for him.
At that time, there was an old brÄhman whose appearance was ugly and repulsive, disliked by people, who came from a distant place.
When the prince saw him, he ordered him to sit down, served water and food, and later asked:
What is the reason for your coming here?
Is it not because of the faults of being disgusted with the household life?
When you are young, you should indulge in the five desires at home. Now that you are old and the time of death is approaching, it is a very good thing to abandon and come to cultivate the path.
Here it is quiet and secluded, without the faults of a household. If you enjoy this, I will always provide you with sweet fruits and cold water, and not let you lack anything.
The brÄhman said:
One without thoughts of desire should dwell here. I now still cannot eliminate thoughts of desire, and therefore I cannot dwell here.
Great sage!

You may observe it yourself. Although my body is old, with white hair and lost teeth, walking unsteadily, eyes blurred, tongue dry, mouth parched unable to speak, head heavy and difficult to support like a great mountain, ears unable to hear clearly, and the body decaying, I still have lustful thoughts like when I was young.
Great Sage!
You should know that I am old and weak, poor and destitute, lacking servants. If you wish to fulfill my original vow, please give me two slave servants.
When the Bodhisattva heard this, he thought:
Strange!
If I say I don't have them today, it goes against my original vow;
If I say I do, but am actually poor and empty.
The brÄhman said:
You are hesitating now, what are you thinking?
Are you worried that I am not a brÄhman who upholds precepts, has extensive learning, and is a learned person?
If you have such worries, I truly am.
The Bodhisattva replied:
I used to have many servants at home, with overflowing treasuries of gold, silver, and precious treasures.

When I saw beggars at that time, I never said I had nothing. Now, staying here, I did not bring any of it. Where can I get it to match your request? That is why I am hesitating and thinking about this matter.
The brÄhman said:
I am now old and decrepit, exhausted, and have come from afar to beg for what I need. Since you have been here, you have never said to any beggar:
'I have nothing.'
Why do you say this today?
Great sage!
If you can take pity and give me the two slaves, I will return to my country;
if you cannot, I will surely die here.
At that time, the prince had this thought:
What expedient means can I use to send this person away?
At that time, the two children were playing in the mountains not far away. They also thought:
We should now make causes and conditions that are not in vain for all sentient beings.
They then called their children, and when the children arrived, the Bodhisattva embraced them and thought again:

My two children have grown up in the deep palace, their bodies are delicate, and they have not experienced cold and suffering. How can they suddenly leave their parents and become servants for others?
He thought again:
For what reason do I consider such matters? If I do not practice difficult and painful practices, how can I attain supreme, perfect enlightenment?
For this reason, I will practice and wish to quickly attain supreme, perfect enlightenment through this practice;

I now give up these two beloved children, not seeking the rewards of rebirth in the heavens, among humans, as a wheel-turning sage king, Åšakra, BrahmÄ, or the four heavenly kings. May this merit all be shared with sentient beings to attain supreme enlightenment.
At that time, the Bodhisattva held the two children with his hands, gave them to the brÄhman, and said these words:
You, brÄhman!

These two children of mine are like my life. They are young and ignorant, not yet understanding human speech. Although they resemble humans, they have not yet learned anything. I now give them to you as servants and attendants. Fearing their mother will come, you should quickly take them away.
At that time, the two children turned around, grabbed their father's clothes, and said to their father:
Father, for what reason do you now give us, your two brothers, to this evil brÄhman?
From now on we will be forever separated from our parents. We are young and do not know anything. Without protection or care, how can we survive?
Why do we have to suffer this pain?

Now, having fallen into the hands of others, my life will certainly not be preserved. If one violates the king's laws, one will receive punishment. We are foolish and young, and have not committed any offenses. Why do we now witness this suffering?
Even if we had actually committed offenses, we would still hope for forgiveness and release. How much more so when we have committed no offense, yet are unjustly wronged?

If our father has already cut off his loving heart towards us, but for the sake of the Dharma, he should not act in such a way. The old and young are pitiable, and there are both the foolish and the wise. Why does our father now inflict such bitter suffering?
If it is for the sake of the Dharma that he abandons us, losing his compassion, how can that be the Dharma?
Although I am young, I have also heard it said in the brÄhman Dharma that if one protects one's wife and children, one can be reborn in BrahmÄ Heaven.
At that time, when the Bodhisattva heard these words, his body and mind trembled and he immediately scolded himself:
Why is it so?
Do you not know, mind,
that since ancient times, in the cycle of birth and death, what sentient being has not been a foe?
What is not a son?
Are you now in the dark, blind, and without sight?
Why don't you focus your thoughts and contemplate and discern?
Are you now just for them, taking the two children, and thus agitated?
If death arrives, what will you do then?
At that time, after the Bodhisattva reprimanded his mind, he immediately attained stability and said to the brÄhman:
You quickly take them away.
At that time, the two children said to their father:
Please listen!
Stay for a while, wait for our mother to come, and then we will kneel and bow, bid farewell, and leave without delay.
The Bodhisattva replied:
You two just go, I and your mother will follow behind you.
At that time, the brÄhman took the two children and quickly set off.
At that time, the two children followed the road and looked back, gazing at their father's face, crying sadly.
At that time, the Bodhisattva reprimanded his mind again:

You should not move again. Observe the burning of old age and death of the body. Before the son has gone far, make a vow again. I now give up my son, which is truly difficult to do. May this cause and condition enable me to attain supreme perfect enlightenment, and remove all the bonds of sentient beings.
Then, when the brÄhman had taken a few steps, he thought:
How amazing! The prince is rare in the world. As he says, he practices and gives me his two sons. The good dharmas he cultivates are fully accomplished.
Where should I sell these two sons now?
Only by returning to the country of my ancestral king.
Then, the brÄhman took the two sons and went to the king's palace. At that time, the ancestral king saw his two grandsons and was filled with a mixture of sadness and joy. He asked the brÄhman:
Where did you get these two children?
The brÄhman said:
Listen!
In the snowy mountains, there is a king's son named SarvÄrthanÄman, who has given these two sons to me as slaves.
When the king heard these words, he clenched his fists and said:
Strange!
My son's love for the Dharma is excessive, to the point where he does not even spare his beloved children;
I will return them to you and give you a reward.
The brÄhman said:
I respectfully follow the king's order.
He then accepted the precious treasures and returned to his home.

At that time, the Bodhisattva's wife was in the empty forest. Her left eye twitched, and her heart was startled and unhappy. The various flowers she had picked withered immediately. Two fruits in her vessel burst out and fell to the ground. Her two breasts trembled, and milk flowed out by itself. A bird cried out in front of her, and she thought like this:
This auspicious sign must be inauspicious. Is it that my husband's life is about to end?
Or have my children been eaten by tigers, wolves, or vicious beasts?
Or did you fall off a mountain while playing and die?
Having thought this, she returned to her dwelling and saw the Bodhisattva sitting near a rock, leaning on a grass mat. She thought:
My husband is here, there is no other concern.
She then went forward and said:
Are the two children now safe and well?
The Bodhisattva replied:
The two children are safe and well.
His wife said again:
Although I truly hear that they are safe and well, I am still worried because I have not seen it myself.
The Bodhisattva replied:
You just sit for a moment, and you will see them.
His wife then sat back down and said again:
Do you not know my original vow?
Everything I have must be given to others.
After you left this morning, a Brahmin came and begged from me, so I gave away my two children to him.
When his wife heard these words, her mind became confused and overwhelmed, and she fell to the ground in a faint, beating her body.
At that time, the Bodhisattva sprinkled water on her, and after being sprinkled with water, she regained consciousness. Her body trembled, and she sat and spoke a verse, saying:
Alas! For the sake of the true Dharma, you are practicing austerities,
When giving away your son, how can your mind be undisturbed?
Your mind is not made of hard iron, and you have not yet permanently severed attachment,
How can you be able to give your son away to others?
My son is still young, upright and incomparable,
His complexion is like a lotus flower, his eyes like blue lotus flowers;
He eats fruits and nuts himself, and does not cause any trouble,
How can you be so heartless, to give him away to others all of a sudden?ğŸ”½This road has many pebbles and sand, thorns and vicious thorns,
This road has many stones, sand, thorns, and evil thorns,
That person has no compassion or wisdom, where will he be taken?
Have you not seen this?
Those deer and others still come to seek, let alone you as their father.
Do you not see that in this mountain, all the trees and plants,
Because of losing my child, all cry out;
All the trees and plants, do not have any consciousness,
Yet they are still able to be like this, let alone those who have minds.
At that time, there was a plantain tree on the ground, trembling all over. The wife then said:
Your husband also gave away his child, is he not compassionate?
Why is he trembling all over like this?
At that time, the wife thought of her child and wailed, running around in the east and west, unable to find peace.
The Bodhisattva said again:
Very good, very good!
Having already entered the mountains to cultivate wholesome dharmas, how can you allow your mind to suffer such hardships?
In vain you waste your time in a secluded place cultivating the subtle principles of goodness.
Alas, Princess!

Although you have deep wisdom and courageous diligence, you are unable to understand the faults of birth and death. Parents, spouses, children, brothers, and enemies - who can recognize their roots in this?

Seeing your child in the past, he may have been your enemy. If he encounters suffering, you will rejoice. Now he is your child, and you are immediately worried. Even if he dies and is forcibly taken away, can you still give rise to anger towards me?
You have not heard the words of the sages:
Whether young, middle-aged, or old, all return to death, just as ripe fruit naturally falls to the ground,
Have you not observed that all birth and death is like seeing false things in a dream?
Impermanence and birth and death lead all beings, even if they have parents, who can save them?
It is like a lion seizing deer, even if they have a mother, it cannot save them.
Old age, sickness and death always harm sentient beings, like a fruit tree picked by many people,
It is like a clay vessel encountering rain from the heavens, all of it rotten and destroyed without any remainder.
The sentient beings of the three realms are also like this, encountering the rain of impermanence, there is no one who can escape it,
Now planning this work, clearly creating that matter, attached to pleasure, not observing, not aware of death's arrival.
Thus, these two children will definitely be given away. I now give them to others for the sake of the Dharma;
You should rejoice, and should not be sorrowful. Although I give away my children, the children will certainly be at ease, therefore you should not give rise to great suffering and distress.
After the prince Bodhisattva said these words, his wife was silent and did not say anything further.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, immediately had this thought:
How strange! The Bodhisattva!
I will give them to you without any regret.
He then transformed his body into a brahman, went to the bodhisattva, and spoke a verse, saying:
Great sage, you should know that your fame has penetrated to the Brahma Heaven.
You are able to practice great giving and delight in the true Dharma.
What I now seek and ask for is indeed not much to say.
I only wish that the great true Dharma will fulfill my wishes.
The bodhisattva replied:
I now have no regard for my body and life for the sake of all, let alone other external things, money, wealth, and precious treasures. Even if I had them, I would truly not cherish them.
When I was originally at home, I had many treasuries, elephants, horses, carriages, male and female servants, and workers. I gave them all to the brahmanas without any stinginess.
But now I am empty-handed and have nothing. Only my body and wife. If you must have them, I truly do not cherish them.
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:
If you can do that, then you can give your wife to me as a gift.
The Bodhisattva replied:
The mind of jealousy and stinginess has long been abandoned by me.
You listen for a moment, and I will speak the Dharma for you.
The Bodhisattva said to his wife:
This brÄhmaá¹‡a is begging me for you. What do you think?
His wife replied:
I am at your disposal. Since I now belong to you, how can I have my own way?
She then took her wife's hand and gave her to the brÄhmaá¹‡a.
At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a said to the Bodhisattva:

This woman has a dignified appearance, a beautiful body, and is the most excellent in complexion. The roads are dangerous with many bandits. If I go alone, I will certainly not reach my destination. For now, I will return her to you as a deposit. Do not give her to anyone else.
The Bodhisattva said again:
Now I rely on you to destroy the prison and sever the bonds. Do you now want to return me to the prison and bind me again?
The brÄhman said:
If you have compassion, and if you can definitely obtain it, I wish to return and receive it for a short while.
Because the Bodhisattva had compassion, he briefly accepted it again, and in the end, what suffering was there?
The brÄhman said:
If I miss the deadline and cannot return, be sure not to give it to anyone else again. It already belongs to me and cannot be given at will.
Having said this, he then left.
Not far from here, he transformed again into another brÄhman, returned to where the Bodhisattva was, and said:

You are the supreme benefit to all beings, like a fruit tree that always produces sweet fruits. I have long admired your reputation from afar, and therefore I have come here, hoping to fulfill my wishes.
The Bodhisattva replied:
I only have one wife, whom I have already given to others. Now I only have my body, which I can still control. If you need anything, I will provide it for you.
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:
I do not need your body, I only need your two eyes. If you can give them to me, it shows deep sincerity.
At that time, the Bodhisattva thought like this:
This brÄhmaá¹‡a is begging me for my eyes, what will he do with them?
He further thought:
What do I have to think about?
This body is like a corpse in a charnel ground, using the impermanent to trade for the permanent, I should be joyful, what is there to consider?
At that time, the Bodhisattva took a ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a wood stick and made a vow, saying:
I now completely abandon my two eyes for all sentient beings, without any greed or stinginess;
I previously gave up my wife and used her to make offerings to others. I wish that this merit will cause sentient beings to forever cut off greed and desire;
The causal conditions of giving my children are to make them part with the habit of attachment;
Now, in giving my two eyes, I will cause all beings to attain the pure Dharma eye.
Having made this vow, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva then took a wooden splinter and was about to pick at his eyes.
At that time, the brÄhman immediately came forward and grabbed his hand, saying:
Do not pick them out yet! My eyes now belong to me. Do not give them to anyone else.
The Bodhisattva replied:
How can I, with this one body, accept two entrustments on the same day?
The first brÄhman has already entrusted his wife to me, and now you entrust your eyes to me. How can I protect them?
At that time, the brÄhman immediately revealed his true form as Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra and said to the Bodhisattva:
Both my wife and eyes belong to me. I now entrust them to you. Do not give them to anyone else.
At that time, Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra immediately flew away. In the sky, he rained down four kinds of flowers. A voice in the sky proclaimed to the devas:
You should know that this person will grow the tree of enlightenment and will soon attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
The practice of dÄna pÄramitÄ by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas is like this, with nothing left to abandon.
If all sentient beings hear this, they should all rejoice in the bodhisattva.
When the bodhisattva practices giving, he acts with a determined mind,
Even the evil one, MÄra, is unable to interrupt him.
I have heard this before:
In the past, there was a king named Subhadra;
In order to accomplish the path of enlightenment, he always practiced benefiting and cultivating the true Dharma, and had no thoughts of using weapons or violence towards sentient beings.

His facial features were upright, rare in the world, his speech was always accompanied by a smile, without coarseness or roughness, he made offerings to his parents, respected elders, and had reverence for Å›ramaá¹‡as and renunciant practitioners.
He himself practiced the ten wholesome deeds, and also encouraged others to practice them. He always practiced giving, without interruption.

If there were poor and destitute people, with emaciated bodies and insufficient clothing, the bodhisattva, upon seeing them, would immediately feel compassion, his whole body trembling as if struck by a poisoned arrow. He would think to himself:

These sentient beings, due to the causes and conditions of stinginess and greed, are ignorant people. Although they have received human form, their appearance is complete, but due to lack of blessings, they always beg from others.
This is all due to their unwillingness to give in their past lives, being covered by stinginess and jealousy;
The retribution of their present life has ripened, and they experience this suffering.

It is like a foolish and ignorant farmer who, traveling far to his wife's family, becomes hungry and thirsty on the road. Having entered their house, he finds no one there, so he steals rice and stuffs his mouth full. Before he can swallow it, the family members arrive. The man feels ashamed and cannot swallow it, yet he is too stingy to spit it out.
The family members saw this and asked him:
What is wrong with you that you are like this?
This person heard this but remained silent and said nothing.

At that time, the wife's family members, both young and old, took a good doctor to treat him. Seeing that his mouth and cheeks were as hard as wood and stone, they had no other plan but to cut open this person's two cheeks with a knife.
After cutting them open, there was no pus or filth, but they saw raw rice filling his mouth. This person's karmic retribution for concealing the theft was seen in the present life.
It was like a woman concealing her pregnancy. On the day of delivery, she suffers greatly and cries out loudly, causing everyone to know about it.

People are also like this. When the karmic retribution for concealing various offenses matures, they are tormented by suffering and it is revealed to the world. Sometimes they suffer because of stinginess and jealousy in their hearts.
I will now block all paths, not allowing stinginess and jealousy to enter my mind. I will now gather all my giving, and settle sentient beings in the practice of giving.
At that time, King Subhadra, having thought this, always practiced giving without rest. When he was giving, his mind was filled with immeasurable joy.
At that time, Mara Paplyas was sorrowful and unhappy, and said these words:
How strange!
Subhadra!
How can you suddenly become my enemy and want to destroy my realm?
I have great power and can subdue all sages, those who drink water, eat fruit, and practice austerities, and those who are skilled in performing spells.
I shoot the flower arrow, and even if I shoot it once, it will cause those who uphold the precepts to be completely destroyed, like a great tree blown over by the wind.
Now, although I, Paplyas, shoot three arrows, I am afraid I cannot cause Bodhisattva Subhadra's body and mind to waver.
Why is this?

The non-Buddhist sages lack the wisdom and compassionate mind. They do not seek to benefit others but only their own happiness. Therefore, they were shot by the arrow and immediately scattered and fled.

The bodhisattva SubhÅ«ti has great wisdom and a thick compassionate mind. He does not seek his own happiness but always acts for the sake of all. Even if I shoot three times now, I am afraid it will not be able to make him scatter and flee.
Why is this?
This person will definitely seek the unsurpassed path for the sake of all beings and will soon attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
And before that, I may be able to create obstacles and cause him to completely break down.
It is like a person who has just encountered suffering and illness. If a doctor gives them a little medicine, they can be cured.
It is also like a small tree, when it first grows, it can be cut down with a fingernail. But when it grows large, even with a hundred axes it is still difficult to cut it down;
This bodhisattva has not yet attained the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, so he will quickly destroy it.
At that time, King Subhadra practiced much giving, and while resting alone in quiet sitting,
at that time, Mara was above in the sky, his body emitting light blocking the sun and moon, and he said these words:
Great King Subhadra!
Excellent, excellent!
You are now truly able to seek the true Dharma and love sentient beings, just as a loving mother loves her child.
Good man!

You wish to increase all wholesome dharmas, but you are instead fanning the flames of all unwholesome dharmas, just as a person who wishes to eat nectar eats poison, who wishes for happiness but instead enters a thief, who wishes to be at ease but instead takes the wrong medicine, who wishes to quench thirst but drinks salty water, who wishes to end sexual desire but instead enjoys many women.
Good man!
Do you not know?
There are some donors who, due to the causes and conditions of giving, all fall into hell. Therefore, I now have compassion for you and explain it in various ways. You should uphold it.
From now on, you should cut off thoughts of giving and give rise to a stingy mind.
At that time, PÄpÄ«yÄn transformed into a hell filled with sinful people, and showed it to SubhÅ«ti, saying:
Such people, all because in their past lives they liked to give and greedily sought the true Dharma, therefore today they have all fallen into this and are experiencing great suffering.
Great King, you should know that the sinners here only use swords and axes to cut each other, and their limbs and joints all fall to the ground, yet they still do not die.
They are wrapped all around with hot copper sheets, and smoke rises from their entire bodies, yet their lives are not extinguished.
Although a thousand nails are driven into their bodies, it is like stretching an ox hide, and they still do not die.
Running east and west, they always encounter raging fires, cold and hot winds, which torment their bodies;

There are evil winds that scatter their bodies, or they are beaten until they are like dust, hungry they swallow iron pellets, thirsty they drink molten copper, they either enter a forest of swords and climb a sword tree, or in a large cauldron they rise and fall in the boiling water, being crushed like ripe beans.
Although these sentient beings experience such various sufferings, their life force still refuses to end.

Great King, you should know that I now have nothing to seek or desire from the king, nor do I seek offerings, because the king practices deviant ways, and therefore I now expound the right path for him.
At that time, King Subhadra, seeing such sentient beings in hell, gave rise to a compassionate mind and had this thought:
